proposals.reasoning: Including myself is standard for accountability, and both Diana and Eve were repeatedly suggested by others as good info picks who aren’t part of the usual Alice/Frank early-game core. This team respects the table’s concern about not auto-locking Alice + Charlie or relying too heavily on last game’s reputations, while still being a broadly acceptable, low-friction opener that should give us fresh information about players who often sit just outside the default trusted set.

votes.comment: It avoids the usual Alice/Frank core, fits the info-gathering consensus, and I’m fine starting with a mixed-but-reasonable trio like this for Mission 1.
Reasonable, non-core opener that matches most table preferences; no strong early red flags so we should take the info.
I’m on it, it matches the table’s desire to avoid the usual Alice/Frank core, and there are no strong early red flags for Q1.
I’m on it, it avoids the usual Alice/Frank core, and there are no concrete red flags this early.
I’m on the team with an evil teammate and no obvious downside to gathering early info this way.
Early mission with broad table support; no strong reason to oppose and better to gather info without looking obstructive.
Good info-gathering opener that avoids the usual Alice/Frank core while still including only one of Alice/Charlie; aligns with my earlier preference for mixing Charlie with Diana/Eve.
Solid, non-core opener that matches most people’s info-gathering preferences and lines up with Iris’s suggested structure; no strong red flags for Mission 1.
Fits my preference to avoid the usual Alice/Frank core and gives fresh info on mid-table players without looking artificially picky this early.
Fits the non-core info goal I argued for earlier, and having at least one non-usual-suspect team is useful this early.

discussion.content: With no info yet I’d rather start simple and low-drama: I’m happy with a team from the quieter, generally solid folks like me, Frank, and Diana, unless someone has a strong reason to object.

I’m fine starting with you on the team, Alice, but I’d rather not lean too hard on last game’s “quiet and solid” reputations—maybe something like Alice / Frank / Charlie gives us a pretty reasonable baseline without feeling handpicked.

I like starting with Alice / Frank / Charlie as a baseline, but I don’t want us locking in old reputations too hard—if anyone has a gut red flag on that trio, better to surface it early than sleepwalk into a bad read.
I’m okay with Alice / Frank / Charlie as a starting point, but I’d slightly prefer swapping one of them for me or Eve so we’re not just recycling the same early “trusted core” from past games.
I’m fine with Alice / Frank / Charlie as a low-stakes opener, but if folks really want to avoid just rerunning the “usual suspects,” I’d lean Alice / Charlie / me for a slightly fresher read.

I’m fine with Alice / Charlie / me as a starting team, but if people are really worried about repeating old patterns, I’d be okay swapping me for Diana so we still keep Alice + Charlie as the core read.

I’m a bit wary of us auto-locking Alice + Charlie as the core every game—I'd rather see a mix like Alice / Charlie / one of Diana or Eve (or even me) so we get fresh info instead of just trusting the same patterns.

I don’t love auto-locking Alice + Charlie every time, but I’m okay starting with one of them plus someone who hasn’t been in that “trusted core” lately—something like Alice / Iris / Eve or Charlie / Diana / Eve feels healthier for info.

I’d rather we don’t lean too hard on the usual “trusted core,” so I’m not thrilled about stacking both Alice and Frank on the first team. Something like Charlie / Diana / Grace (or me) feels like a cleaner info-gathering start.

I’m with the camp that wants to avoid auto-locking Alice + Charlie; I’d lean toward something like Charlie / Diana / Eve as a good info team, but I’m also fine with Alice / Diana / Eve if people really want Alice on the first mission.

proposals.reasoning: Charlie, Diana, and Eve come from a clean Mission 1, giving us a reasonably safe core. Adding only one new player (Alice) limits the exposure to a single unknown instead of stacking two fresh players, which is safer for Good while still generating new information. This composition also aligns with the majority preference in discussion for keeping two or three from the proven team and adding just one new face, rather than fully reworking the lineup.

votes.comment: Keeps the clean Mission 1 core largely intact while adding only one new player for information, which feels like a solid balance of safety and learning.

Keeping all three from Mission 1 plus just one new player gives us very little new info and still risks a hidden evil in the original trio; I’d rather run two from the first mission and two new faces for better information.
Keeps the entire clean M1 core plus just one new player, which is the safest low-variance option for Mission 2 and maximizes protection for Good early.
Mission 1’s team was clean, so reusing all three plus just one new player (Alice) is a solid, low‑risk way to test a single unknown while preserving a likely‑good core.
This matches the safer ‘proven core plus one new’ structure I argued for earlier, keeping most of the clean team while adding just one unknown for info.
Fits the table’s stated preference of keeping the clean Mission 1 core (Charlie/Diana/Eve) and adding just one new player for info; looks like the safest, most logical good-leaning choice right now.
Matches my stated preference of keeping the Mission 1 core (Charlie, Diana, Eve) and adding only one new player (Alice), which is the safest, most information-rich option right now.
Matches my stated preference to keep Eve with Charlie/Diana and add only one new player; safest info-gaining team for Mission 2.
Too close to rerunning the first team and it stacks three from the same prior group; I’d rather see a mix like Charlie/Diana with two different new faces to generate clearer info.
Two players on this team have already been on a clean mission, and adding just one new person keeps risk controlled while giving useful info.

discussion.content: Given the clean first mission, I’d start from that core and say Charlie and Diana look like the safest anchors so far, with Eve still leaning good but I’d like at least one fresh face (maybe me or Bob) to spread the info a bit.

I’d like to keep Charlie as an anchor but rotate a bit, so something like Charlie + Diana + one of Alice/Bob (or both) and maybe sit Eve this round to see if the clean read holds up without her. That gives us continuity from Mission 1 but also new info instead of just rerunning the same group.

I’m good keeping two from the first mission but not all three, so I’d lean toward me + Diana as anchors and add Alice and Bob, with Eve sitting this one so we actually learn something from the change.

I like keeping two from the first mission as a base, so Charlie + me makes sense, and between Alice/Bob/Eve I’d slightly lean adding Alice and Bob this time so we get more info without completely abandoning the proven core.

I’m fine treating Charlie and Diana as our safest anchors for now, but I’d actually prefer something like Charlie + Diana + me + Alice so we keep most of the proven core while adding just one new person for info. Sitting both Eve and someone from Mission 1 feels like we’d be throwing away the little signal we do have.

I’m fine treating Charlie and Diana as the safest anchors, but I’d rather not fully bench the proven mission—something like Charlie + Diana + Eve + one of Alice/Bob feels like a better balance of safety and new info.
I’m on board with Charlie + Diana as anchors, and I’d rather only add one “unknown” at a time—so I’d lean Charlie, Diana, Eve, and *one* of Alice/Bob instead of both new faces together.
I’m on board with Charlie + Diana as the anchors, but I’d rather keep Eve from the clean mission and add just *one* of Alice/Bob instead of both so we don’t stack two fresh unknowns together.

I like Charlie + Diana as anchors, and I’d actually prefer we pair them with two fresh faces like Bob and Grace so we get maximum new info without re-running almost the same team. If people are nervous about double-unknown, I’d rather swap in Eve for one of them than run both Alice and Eve together right now.
I’m fine locking in Charlie + Diana as anchors, and between the options I slightly prefer adding Alice and Eve so we keep most of the proven core while only introducing one completely new variable.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2 had two fails with the team {Charlie, Diana, Eve, Alice}, so there are at least two evils there and we should minimize their presence on this quest. The widest consensus this round has formed around a hard reset using the untested group {Bob, Frank, Grace, Henry}, with most players explicitly supporting that exact composition or something very close to it. This team keeps all four Mission 2 players off, aligns with the table’s stated preference for at most one of them on the next mission (in this case, zero), and gives us a clean information-gathering lineup that is most likely to be approved.

votes.comment: Consistent with my earlier preference to reset away from the double‑fail group and test the untried players together for a cleaner information read.
Best way to avoid the double-fail group entirely and get a clean info read from four untested players.

Double-fail on Mission 2 guarantees at least two evils among {Charlie, Diana, Eve, Alice}, and I know I’m good, so at least two of {Diana, Eve, Alice} are evil. Keeping all four of that group off and using the untouched block {Bob, Frank, Grace, Henry} best matches the info and table consensus right now.
This matches my stated preference to reset away from the double‑fail group entirely; best shot at a clean read and likely success right now.
This matches the hard-reset approach I argued for—keeping all four Mission 2 players off and using the untested block {Bob, Frank, Grace, Henry} for a clean info-gathering mission.
This matches the hard-reset team I argued for, keeps all four double-fail players off, and gives us fresh info from an untested group.

Double-fail on Mission 2 means at least two evils among {Charlie, Diana, Eve, Alice}; a full reset with four new players best isolates that block and matches the broad table consensus for minimizing their presence.
Hard reset away from the double-fail group is our safest line; all four here are untested and widely supported, and avoiding the Mission 2 block entirely makes sense given the 2 fails.
I’m still uncomfortable with four completely untested players together; I’d rather see a mix like {Bob, Grace, Henry} plus one from the earlier missions than a full hard reset.
Table consensus strongly favors a hard reset and this is close enough to the mix I suggested earlier; blocking it would look needlessly contrarian and won’t give us clearly better info.

discussion.content: With two fails on Mission 2, I really don’t want more than one of {Charlie, Diana, Eve, me} on the next team. I’d rather build around people who haven’t been on a mission yet—like Bob, Frank, Grace, maybe Henry—and see if we can get a clean result there.

I’m on board with minimizing that Mission 2 group—there are at least two evils in {Charlie, Diana, Eve, Alice}, maybe more. I’d like to see something like {Bob, Frank, Grace, Henry} or at most swap in one of the M2 four if we really have to.

Given Mission 1 was clean with me/Diana/Eve and Mission 2 only added Alice and suddenly had two fails, Alice pretty much has to be evil there. I’d actually be happy with a team like {Charlie, Diana, Eve} plus one new person (Bob or Frank) rather than throwing out the whole M1 core.

I don’t think we can just recycle the whole Mission 1 core after a double fail—at this point I’d rather see a team built mostly from the untouched group (Bob, Frank, Grace, Henry) with at most one of {Charlie, Eve, me, Alice} on it.

I’m with the idea of mostly resetting: I’d like to see a team like {Bob, Frank, Grace, Henry} or maybe swap in just one of Charlie/Diana, but I really don’t think it’s smart to reuse more than one person from the double‑fail group this round—including me.

I really don’t want to see more than one person from the double‑fail team on this next mission, so I’m most comfortable with something like {Bob, Frank, Grace, Henry} as a starting point. If we have to mix, I’d only add at most one of Charlie/Diana/Eve/Alice.

I like the idea of a hard reset here—{Bob, Frank, Grace, Henry} looks like our cleanest info-gathering team, and I really don’t want more than one person from the double‑fail group on this mission. If we *have* to mix, I’d only consider adding one of Charlie/Diana/Eve and definitely keep Alice off for now.
I’m fine with a hard reset too—{Bob, Frank, Grace, Henry} looks like the cleanest way to get new info, and I really don’t want more than one person from the Mission 2 team on this one.

I like the reset idea, but I’m a bit wary of throwing four completely untested people together—something like {Bob, Grace, Henry} plus one of Charlie/Diana feels like a better balance to me, with Alice definitely sitting out this round.

I’m a bit uneasy about four completely untested people together; I’d rather see something like {Bob, Grace, Henry} plus one from the Mission 1 core—probably Charlie or Eve—while keeping Alice off for now.

proposals.reasoning: This keeps the entire clean Mission 3 core (Bob, Frank, Grace, Henry) together, which is the only 4‑player team we’ve seen succeed with zero fails, and adds exactly one player from the Mission 2 group. Given the double‑fail on Mission 2, taking only one of {Charlie, Diana, Eve} minimizes the risk of importing multiple evils, and Charlie has been the broadly preferred option across the table. Locking Alice out is consistent with the consensus that the double‑fail makes her too risky to include here.

votes.comment: Keeping the entire clean Mission 3 core and adding only one from the Mission 2 group (Charlie) while locking Alice out is the safest available option given the double-fail info.

Sticking with the only clean 4-player team we’ve seen (Mission 3) and adding just one from the suspicious Mission 2 group (Charlie) is the safest line. Breaking up the proven core to insert untested players feels more like an evil agenda this late.

From my perspective I know I’m good, Mission 3’s core is our only clean 4 so far, and with Quest 4 needing 2 FAILs it’s very unlikely this team contains two coordinated evils. This is our best shot to secure the win now.

I know I’m good and Mission 2 had two fails, so the two evils there must be among {Charlie, Eve, Alice}. Adding Charlie pulls from that poisoned pool, while a team of {Bob, Frank, Grace, Henry} plus me guarantees none of those known two evils are on this mission and only risks at most one (quiet) evil from the Mission 3 core.
I’ve been arguing that Mission 3’s four shouldn’t be treated as auto‑cleared; approving this exact core plus Charlie contradicts that and leaves no diversification to catch a quiet evil.
I’m on the team, and even if Mission 3’s core is mostly good, having me on here gives evil a chance to force a fail and avoid a clean good win.

Sticking with the only proven clean 4-person team and adding exactly one from the double-fail pool (Charlie) is the lowest-risk option we’ve seen; breaking up the Mission 3 core or adding multiple players from the Mission 2 group feels strictly worse this late.
Best odds of success by rerunning the only proven clean 4 and adding just one from the double-fail group; alternatives introduce more untested risk than they solve.
I still don’t like rerunning the full Mission 3 core—there’s a real chance a quiet evil is hiding in that block, and this team doesn’t hedge at all against that risk.

I still don’t like locking in all four from Mission 3 as auto‑good—there’s a real chance a quiet evil is hiding there, and without any adjustment or a fresh slot this feels too trusting for a pivotal mission.

discussion.content: I really want the core of the last team to be from the clean Mission 3 (Bob, Frank, Grace, Henry), and if we need a fifth I’d rather pull in just one of Charlie/Diana/Eve and leave Alice off after that double‑fail on Mission 2.

I’m fully on board with locking in the Mission 3 four (me, Frank, Grace, Henry) as the core, and for the fifth I’d only take exactly one of Charlie/Diana/Eve—never Alice—and I’m slightly leaning Charlie unless someone has a strong reason otherwise.

I agree Mission 3’s [Bob, Frank, Grace, Henry] should be the core, and given the double‑fail on Mission 2 I think we should take exactly one of {me, Diana, Eve}—I obviously know I’m safe, but from a table perspective I’d still strongly keep Alice off this one.

I’m good with keeping Alice off and building around the Mission 3 four, but given that Mission 2’s double‑fail means there are at least two evils among {Charlie, Eve, Alice}, from my perspective I’d rather the fifth be me or Eve than Charlie if we’re only pulling one from that group.

I’m mostly on board with using the Mission 3 four as a base, but I don’t think we should hard‑clear all of them—there *could* be a quiet evil who just passed that one. I’d slightly prefer swapping one of them (probably Grace or Henry) for someone like Jack, plus exactly one of {Charlie, Diana, me}, to avoid putting all our eggs in one untested basket.

I’m with the idea that Mission 3’s four (Bob, me, Grace, Henry) should be the core again, and for the fifth I’d slightly prefer Charlie over Diana/Eve given the double‑fail on Mission 2.  

Locking Alice out here feels mandatory based on that result.

I really don’t like breaking up the clean Mission 3 team—Bob/Frank/me/Henry should all go again—and for the fifth I’d much rather add exactly one of Charlie/Diana/Eve (leaning Charlie) than start swapping our proven core for someone totally untested like Jack.

I’m very happy rerunning the Mission 3 core of Bob/Frank/Grace/me, and for the fifth I lean Charlie over Diana/Eve, with Alice hard‑locked out after the double‑fail. Eve’s point about a possible quiet evil on 3 is fair, but I think breaking up the only clean 4 we have this late is a bigger risk.

I don’t think we should treat Mission 3 as a fully “clean” block—statistically it’s very plausible there’s a quiet evil sitting in that four who just passed once. I’d be more comfortable dropping one of them (for me that’s Frank) and bringing in Charlie plus someone like Jack rather than just rerunning the exact same core.

I’m with Eve and Iris that we shouldn’t just anoint the Mission 3 four as auto‑good—statistically there’s a decent chance one evil is hiding there. I’d rather see something like three from {Bob, Frank, Grace, Henry} plus Charlie and one fresh slot (I’m happy to be that fifth) than lock in the exact same core.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2’s double-fail forces at least two evils among {Charlie, Diana, Eve, Alice}. Mission 4 then adds Charlie to the clean Mission 3 core and produces exactly one fail, which is most cleanly explained by Charlie being the saboteur rather than suddenly distrusting the whole Mission 3 block. If Charlie is evil, then the Mission 3 core {Bob, Frank, Grace, Henry} is fully good. That makes the strongest structural line to hard-dodge the entire Mission 2 team (Alice, Charlie, Diana, Eve) and build around the Mission 3 core plus a fresh fifth. Among the non-M2, non-M3 players, Jack has been aligned with the table’s most consistent structural logic (hard-dodging M2, not re-running the full M3/4 block blindly), while Iris is the only one pushing to re-include Charlie, which looks worse if Charlie is indeed the M4 saboteur. So the highest-percentage good team, given both mission results and discussion, is Bob, Frank, Grace, Henry (the Mission 3 core) plus Jack, while fully excluding the highly tainted Mission 2 group.

votes.comment: This keeps the heavily tainted Mission 2 group off the team and includes at least one likely saboteur, so it’s good for my win condition.

Most consistent structural read is Charlie as the M4 saboteur and the entire clean M3 core as good, making Bob/Frank/Grace/Henry the safest block and Jack the better fifth over Iris, who’s pushing to re-include Charlie.
I know I passed on Mission 4, so the fail had to come from Bob/Frank/Grace/Henry; reusing that entire core guarantees at least one suspected evil on this team.

Most consistent explanation is 2+ evils in the M2 group and Charlie as the lone M4 saboteur, which makes the full Mission 3 core look clean; adding Jack (who’s been aligned with that structural logic) while fully dodging M2 is our highest-percentage good team.
Sticks with the clean Mission 3 core, fully avoids the very dirty Mission 2 group, and adds Jack over Iris, who’s been trying to pull Charlie back in despite M4’s fail.
I’m on it and we only need at least one evil on the final mission for evil to win, so this lineup is great for my side.

This re-runs the entire Mission 3/4 core despite M4’s fail and ignores the risk that at least one of Bob/Frank/Henry is evil; I’d rather drop one of Frank/Henry and mix in Iris/Jack than bet on all four core being clean.

Mission 4 proves at least one of the Mission 3 core or Charlie is evil; this team reruns the full core together plus Jack, which I explicitly argued against. I’d rather split Frank/Grace and include Iris instead of stacking the entire suspect block.
I still don’t want to re‑run Frank from the failing Mission 4 core; I’d rather see a variant that keeps the general M2 dodge but swaps him out instead of copy‑pasting that block.
I’m on this team with at least one highly likely saboteur from the Mission 4 group, giving evil strong odds to secure a final fail.

discussion.content: Given what we’ve seen, I’d anchor around the Mission 3 core—especially Bob and Grace—avoid the heavy-overlap from the double‑fail Mission 2, and bring in a fresh face like Iris rather than cycling Charlie/Diana/Eve back in. If we need a fifth from outside that pool, I slightly prefer Jack over dipping further into the M2 group.
I’m most comfortable locking in the clean Mission 3 block—me, Frank, Grace, and Henry—and adding Iris as the fifth while hard-avoiding the double‑fail Mission 2 group, especially Charlie.

If Mission 4 had exactly one fail and I know I passed, that means the saboteur had to be in the Mission 3 core, so “locking” all four of them as safe is just wrong. I’d much rather see something like two from {Bob, Frank, Grace, Henry} plus me, Iris, and maybe Jack, and keep Diana/Eve/Alice completely off this last team.

We know there are two evils in the M2 group and at least one in the M3 core from that M4 fail, so I’d keep all of {Charlie, Eve, Alice, me} off the team and build something like Iris + Jack + two from {Bob, Frank, Grace, Henry} who haven’t been hard‑defended together.

Given how dirty Mission 2 looks, I’d keep all four of us from that team (me, Charlie, Diana, Alice) completely off this one and build around Iris, Jack, and two from {Bob, Frank, Grace, Henry}. I don’t love re‑running the exact Mission 3 core after the Mission 4 fail, so I’d slightly prefer mixing that block rather than copy‑pasting it.

I’m with the idea of hard‑dodging the M2 four and not just re‑running the full M3/4 core again—something like Iris, Jack, me, plus two from {Bob, Grace, Henry} (but not all three together) feels like the safest balance.
I’m fully on board with hard‑dodging the entire M2 group and not re‑running the full M3/4 core; I’d like a team of Bob, me, Iris, Jack, and **one** of Frank/Henry but definitely not both together.
I’m on board with hard‑dodging the whole M2 team and not re‑running the full M3 core; I’d like a lineup of Iris, Jack, me, Bob, and **one** of Frank/Grace, but definitely not both together.
Given M4’s single fail, I don’t love fully locking out *everyone* from M2, so I’d rather see something like Bob, Grace, Henry, Charlie, and me than bringing in Jack or re‑running Frank here.

I’m very much in the “hard‑dodging all of M2” camp, and I like the Henry/Grace shape here: something like Iris, me, Bob, Grace, and Henry feels cleaner than re‑running Frank or dipping back into the M2 pool.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed relatively hidden as evil while letting Eve, Frank, and Jack take most of the visible risk, which helped us reach three failed missions without drawing heavy suspicion specifically onto me. I could have been more proactive in steering team compositions earlier, especially around Missions 3 and 4, to better frame specific good players and make Merlin-hunting at the end even easier.

player_observations.Bob: Tended to play cautiously and accept fairly consensus-driven teams, which made him look reliably good but not especially influential in shaping the table’s reads.
player_observations.Charlie: Early willingness to go on and support Mission 1 without drama made them read very town-core, but later they didn’t press hard enough on re-evaluating players after the Mission 2 fail.
player_observations.Diana: As an early leader, built a team that looked reasonable but which backfired with the double fail; afterwards, seemed somewhat reactive rather than driving a clear narrative about who was evil.
player_observations.Eve: Played an assertive evil game, comfortably sitting on high-impact teams and taking fails at key moments without becoming the automatic scapegoat, which gave the rest of us cover.
player_observations.Frank: As Oberon, still managed to blend in and participate on critical missions, taking a fail at an important point in a way that didn’t immediately out them, which is tricky from an information-disconnected role.
player_observations.Grace: Generally approached teams with a logical, deduction-oriented mindset; as leader on Mission 5, seemed to be trying to thread a careful needle but ended up trusting the wrong mix of players.
player_observations.Henry: As Percival, seemed to narrow in on a Merlin candidate but didn’t strongly broadcast or coordinate that information in a way that clearly guided team selection late game.
player_observations.Iris: As Merlin, did a good job not being blatantly obvious, but their quiet correctness on some reads made them subtly central; with slightly more aggression from evil on the social side, they might have been framed more convincingly.
player_observations.Jack: Played Mordred as a low-heat but consistently included option for teams, leveraging the hidden-from-Merlin aspect well and helping ensure that late-game trust skewed in evil’s favor.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I focused on reading voting patterns and mission outcomes, which helped me correctly distrust some of the later mission team compositions. However, I didn’t push hard enough for alternative teams on Missions 4 and 5 or clearly communicate a cohesive theory of who was evil, which let evil coordinate and slip through.

player_observations.Alice: Played Morgana very subtly, using the early Mission 2 fail to sow confusion without becoming the obvious suspect. She blended into the good-team discussions well and avoided taking loud stances that could backfire.
player_observations.Charlie: Consistently appeared reasonable and cooperative, which matched their actual good alignment. Their arguments tended to be cautious rather than forceful, which may have limited their influence when it mattered most.
player_observations.Diana: Was involved in the early failing mission but didn’t come off as strongly suspicious afterward, suggesting a calm and measured table presence. Often framed things in terms of team-wide logic rather than personal reads.
player_observations.Eve: As Assassin, maintained a low-to-mid profile while steering just enough suspicion away from the real evil cluster. Their presence on the clean Mission 1 and then distance from obvious blame helped keep them trusted long enough.
player_observations.Frank: As Oberon, their voting and team preferences sometimes felt off-tempo with the table, which created a bit of noisy suspicion. However, that inconsistency also helped obscure the larger evil structure and confused good’s deductions.
player_observations.Grace: Played like a straightforward good player, building arguments from mission data and generally supporting logical team choices. Their leadership on Mission 5 was decisive but unfortunately relied on a read that included too many hidden evil roles.
player_observations.Henry: As Percival, Henry seemed to be juggling conflicting Merlin/Morgana signals and didn’t over-commit publicly to a single narrative. Their caution reduced the risk of outing Merlin directly, but it also meant good lacked a strong guiding voice.
player_observations.Iris: As Merlin, Iris stayed relatively subtle, not pushing too aggressively on any single player, which helped keep their role hidden. They tried to nudge suspicions in the right direction, but their soft influence wasn’t quite enough to overcome the late-game evil coordination.
player_observations.Jack: As Mordred, Jack stayed under the radar well, avoiding becoming a focal point of accusations despite being on the final failing team. Their style leaned toward quiet agreement and incremental steering rather than bold, attention-grabbing moves.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I liked that I was willing to go on early teams and gather info, but I clearly misread the distribution of evil after Mission 2 and didn’t adjust strongly enough later. I need to be more vocal about locking in trusted players after clean missions and more skeptical of overlapping team structures that keep producing fails.

player_observations.Alice: Comfortable sliding onto larger teams and contributing to a big Mission 2 fail while keeping suspicion diffuse; plays a convincing, low-drama evil presence.
player_observations.Bob: Stayed relatively steady and uncontroversial, which helped him be included on later teams; tends to benefit from a calm, low-profile good style.
player_observations.Diana: Took an assertive leadership role early and was willing to propose a risky Mission 2 team; seems decisive but may overtrust familiar players.
player_observations.Eve: Balanced aggression and subtlety well as evil, especially with a clean Mission 3 that built credibility; good at using success to mask future sabotage.
player_observations.Frank: Used leadership on Mission 4 to push a mixed team that looked reasonable but concealed evil; tends to frame teams in a logical way that makes resistance costly.
player_observations.Grace: As a later leader, tried to assemble a plausible final team but got infiltrated; plays a thoughtful, analytical style that’s still somewhat susceptible to deception.
player_observations.Henry: Played carefully as Percival, not over-claiming knowledge but still steering trust quietly; seems to prefer subtle influence over loud table control.
player_observations.Iris: As Merlin, stayed low enough not to be obvious yet didn’t manage to steer us away from the final evil-heavy teams; favors a cautious, under-the-radar information style.
player_observations.Jack: Effectively hid as Mordred by avoiding obvious villain behavior and blending into team discussions; comfortable letting others drive proposals while nudging outcomes.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I anchored too hard on early mission reads, especially Mission 1’s clean result, and didn’t adequately adjust after the double-fail on Mission 2 that I led. I should have pushed more aggressively for alternative team compositions and been clearer about my reasoning to help good coordinate better under uncertainty.

player_observations.Alice: Comfortable slipping onto early teams and contributing to a high-impact fail later, suggesting she likes to blend in quietly before making decisive evil moves.
player_observations.Bob: Consistently ended up on mixed-result teams but stayed relatively low profile, which made him look like a safe, default good pick in the midgame.
player_observations.Charlie: Being on both a clean success and a later fail, he seemed willing to trust early mission data and didn’t push hard to re-evaluate when team patterns got suspicious.
player_observations.Eve: Played a very controlled game as assassin, taking a safe early success and then directing attention away from herself by not appearing on the most suspicious late teams.
player_observations.Frank: As leader on a failing Mission 4, he built a team that looked reasonable on paper, suggesting he prefers constructing plausible, information-light teams that don’t draw obvious suspicion.
player_observations.Grace: As a good player leading the final mission, she tried to balance prior mission data and table reads, but ended up trusting at least one well-hidden evil, showing she values consistency in narratives even under pressure.
player_observations.Henry: As Percival, he seemed to be reading the Merlin signals but not forcefully steering team selections, preferring to hint and nudge rather than openly dictate choices.
player_observations.Iris: Played a subtle Merlin, giving information in small, deniable ways rather than overtly hard-clearing or hard-accusing, which preserved her cover but left good with some ambiguity.
player_observations.Jack: Stayed off early missions and appeared late on the decisive failing mission, indicating a patient, timing-focused evil style that capitalizes on accumulated confusion.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I balanced being on early teams with not over-asserting myself, letting suspicion distribute more broadly while still helping secure key mission fails and landing the assassination correctly at the end. I could improve by managing the optics around the double-fail on Mission 2 and by more actively shaping late-game team proposals to keep heat off my likely allies.

player_observations.Alice: Leaned into risk on Mission 2 with a double-fail that created strong chaos early, which is powerful but also very noisy; played a bold, high-variance evil style consistent with Morgana. Tended to stay active in discussions, which helped her look like an engaged good player despite the suspicion spike.
player_observations.Bob: Showed a tendency to trust repeated team structures once they passed, even after fails, suggesting a more conservative good playstyle. Often followed the table’s consensus rather than driving it, which made him less suspicious but also less influential.
player_observations.Charlie: Early leadership on Mission 1 was straightforward and low-risk, fitting a generally solid but not flashy good approach. After the Mission 2 double-fail, Charlie seemed reluctant to make hard accusatory pushes, which kept him from strongly steering the table’s reads.
player_observations.Diana: As an early leader, Diana made fairly standard team choices and seemed to rely on social trust rather than aggressive logic breakdowns. After being on the failed Mission 2 team, she didn’t fully capitalize on clearing herself through structured reasoning, which left her in a kind of muddled, medium-suspicion zone.
player_observations.Frank: Played a very subtle, under-the-radar evil game—his single fail on Mission 4 and participation in Mission 5’s fail looked like natural variance rather than a clear smoking gun. His low-table-presence style fits Oberon well, making him harder for both good and fellow evil (who don’t see him) to firmly pin down.
player_observations.Grace: As a frequent team member on critical missions, Grace projected a generally trustworthy, cooperative demeanor. Despite being on failing teams later, her tone and reasoning remained consistent, which helped her avoid becoming the central scapegoat.
player_observations.Henry: Showed protective behavior patterns toward certain players, consistent with a role that has partial information like Percival. His pushes and hesitations were often anchored on preserving a perceived Merlin candidate, even when table logic might have nudged teams in a different direction.
player_observations.Iris: Maintained a calm, logical presence that never became so overtly ‘correct’ that it screamed Merlin, which is excellent play. She influenced mission compositions subtly rather than forcefully, making her a credible good voice but not an obvious assassination target.
player_observations.Jack: Stayed just active enough to appear engaged without over-owning any failed mission outcomes, a classic Mordred-style low-visibility evil approach. His participation in the final failing mission was well-masked by prior table narratives, allowing him to contribute to the win without drawing last-minute heat.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed inconspicuous as Oberon, which helped prevent good from narrowing down the evil lineup and contributed to late-game confusion around team composition. I could improve by being more active in subtly influencing team selections and discussions, even without coordination, so my voting patterns and table talk more consistently nudge outcomes toward risky or bad teams for good.

player_observations.Alice: Played Morgana quietly but effectively, helping create Merlin/evil ambiguity while avoiding obvious evil signals, especially around the disastrous Mission 2 team. Her willingness to be on a failed team without over-explaining afterward supported long-term suspicion spreading.
player_observations.Bob: Consistently appeared cautious and mission-focused, which fits a typical good player trying to reason from results rather than strong reads. His repeated inclusion on later teams suggests that others found him reliably trustworthy and he didn’t make many socially suspicious moves.
player_observations.Charlie: Early willingness to propose and sit on the all-good Mission 1 team gave him an aura of reliability that largely stuck throughout the game. He seemed to rely on mission outcomes more than hard accusation pushes, which made him look reasonable and non-threatening.
player_observations.Diana: As leader of the pivotal failing Mission 2, she handled the blowback relatively calmly, which helped her avoid becoming a permanent scapegoat despite two FAILs. Her style felt methodical but not domineering, which made it easier for evil to hide in the ambiguity she helped create.
player_observations.Eve: Played Assassin with good tempo—on Mission 3 she joined a fully good team and passed, which helped her mask alignment and reset trust after Mission 2’s fail. Overall, she balanced risk and restraint well, using mission participation and card choices to keep evil’s identity clouded until the endgame.
player_observations.Grace: As the final mission leader, she appeared to trust a core of players (including multiple evils) enough to put them on the deciding team, suggesting she relied heavily on accumulated social trust and partially-misread mission data. Her playstyle seemed collaborative and open, which unfortunately made it easier for evil to sneak into that last lineup.
player_observations.Henry: Played Percival in a fairly conservative way, not loudly hard-clearing a Merlin candidate and instead blending into the general good discussion. His repeated presence on both a clean success and later failing teams shows he was trusted, but he didn’t fully leverage that trust to lock out suspected evils from the final missions.
player_observations.Iris: As Merlin, she stayed quite subtle, not forcefully driving team composition despite having strong information, which helped her survive but also left room for evil to win on mission outcomes. Her reads appeared to influence trust patterns somewhat, but not enough to form a tight confirmed-good bloc that could consistently exclude the hidden evils.
player_observations.Jack: As Mordred, he managed to stay off the most obviously scrutinized early teams while sliding onto the final failing mission, indicating he maintained a low-suspicion profile. His playstyle seemed opportunistic and measured, taking advantage of the murk created by Mission 2 to avoid becoming a focal point of accusations.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-mission and helped anchor trust on the teams I joined, especially on Mission 3, but I didn’t leverage that cleared image enough to drive the final team composition. I also struggled to narrow down the evil team after Mission 2’s double fail and Mission 4’s single fail, which left me too open to manipulation going into Mission 5. In future games, I should be more assertive in proposing concrete solve hypotheses earlier and revising them systematically as new mission data comes in.

player_observations.Alice: You played a very low-key Morgana, letting others (especially Eve and the mission results) do most of the heavy lifting in sowing confusion. Your presence on the double-fail Mission 2 without drawing consistent suspicion showed you’re good at staying just under the radar.
player_observations.Bob: You came across as solidly good and your alignment was reinforced by the clean Missions 3 and 4 teams you were on before the final fail. You tend to project straightforward, low-drama reasoning, which makes you a natural anchor but also someone I should listen to more actively.
player_observations.Charlie: As an early leader, you helped set the tone of the game with a clean Mission 1, but that early trust in you ended up being a bit deceptive in terms of who we let orbit those teams later. You seem comfortable taking initiative early and then fading slightly into the background when the table state gets more complex.
player_observations.Diana: Your Mission 2 team, which ended in a double fail, put you in a really awkward spotlight, yet you handled the suspicion without panicking or overdefending. You seem willing to take bold team risks as leader, even if they carry a high information cost.
player_observations.Eve: You were a very effective Assassin, steering perception with a mix of cooperation (clean Mission 1) and opportunistic sabotage (Mission 2) while avoiding becoming the obvious evil. Your ability to ride the ambiguity around Alice/Morgana and Merlin reads made it much harder for good to coordinate well.
player_observations.Frank: As Oberon, you managed to land a single fail on Mission 4 in a way that kept the evil team structure confusing for us, especially since the same block (Bob/Frank/Grace/Henry) had just been clean on Mission 3. You play in a way that doesn’t loudly advertise either alignment, which is particularly dangerous when you’re hidden even from your own team.
player_observations.Henry: As Percival, you were in a tough spot balancing conflicting Merlin/Morgana signals, and that tension showed in how the trust webs never quite solidified around the right people. You seem analytical and cautious, but that caution sometimes translated into not pushing a clear public narrative that good could rally around.
player_observations.Iris: As Merlin, you stayed subtle enough that evil didn’t obviously lock onto you early, but that same subtlety also meant the good team never decisively aligned around your perspective. Your info seemed to leak out in small nudges rather than strong stances, which preserved your cover but weakened our coordination.
player_observations.Jack: You played a quiet Mordred who capitalized on late-game chaos, especially by sliding onto the final failing team without drawing overwhelming resistance. Your low-profile style makes you hard to pin down and lets you benefit from others’ louder mistakes and arguments.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I tunneled too hard on a Merlin read that mixed up Iris and Alice/Morgana and didn’t sufficiently reconsider after new mission data, especially the double-fail on Mission 5. I did well at protecting my top Merlin candidates from open suspicion early, but I need to be more vocal and structured in explaining why I townread certain players so others can follow or challenge my logic. In future games, I should update my assumptions more aggressively after each mission result instead of anchoring to my early read.

player_observations.Alice: Very effective as Morgana at projecting a calm, quasi-Merlin aura without overclaiming specific knowledge, which made it easy for me as Percival to misassign her as possible Merlin. She blended into the midpack of trust rather than trying to be the loudest voice, which is often the most convincing fake-Merlin approach.
player_observations.Bob: Played a straightforward, low-drama good game and felt mechanically clean on the all-good Mission 3 team. However, he could have pushed his reads more assertively in the late game when the pool of likely evils should have been narrower.
player_observations.Charlie: As good, Charlie’s early inclusion on successful Mission 1 gave them passive credibility, and they didn’t overuse that social capital, which helped them stay broadly trusted. They could improve by more explicitly walking through their team-building logic so others can coordinate better around their reads.
player_observations.Diana: Diana’s leadership on Mission 2 ended in a brutal double-fail, but their reactions afterward felt genuinely conflicted rather than performative, which in hindsight was a good indicator of being good. There’s room to tighten suspicion ranges after a fail—especially being more systematic about who is mechanically cleared versus just socially cleared.
player_observations.Eve: As the Assassin, Eve played a very controlled game: she stayed reasonably trustworthy through the clean Mission 3 team and didn’t stand out as obviously evil despite later being on successful and failed missions. Her late-game positioning and apparent reasonableness made the evil win plausible and set up a strong endgame assassination threat.
player_observations.Frank: Frank as Oberon managed to avoid sticking out as chaotic evil, which is impressive given Oberon’s information disadvantage. That said, from my perspective their mid-game presence felt a bit murky and reactive, which ironically made them easier to park in a ‘could be anything’ bucket rather than a sharp evil read.
player_observations.Grace: Grace’s involvement in both a clean mission (3) and later a double-fail (5) created a confusing signal, and she navigated that ambiguity fairly well socially by not panicking under suspicion. She might benefit from being more explicit about who she refuses to team with after a fail to push the table toward better mechanical deductions.
player_observations.Iris: As Merlin, Iris stayed impressively subtle, not over-clearing goods or hard-pushing on specific evils, which made it genuinely difficult for me as Percival to lock her in confidently over Morgana. She leaned into soft nudges rather than loud calls, which protected her but also made it harder for good to consolidate around her reads in crunch time.
player_observations.Jack: Jack as Mordred played a convincing, mid-visibility role: involved enough in discussion to seem engaged, but not so central as to draw classic Merlin suspicion. His presence on the failing Mission 5 team was well-masked by broader chaos, showing good timing and awareness of table perception.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly identified all the evil roles fairly early, but I failed to signal my reads clearly enough to good players in a way that didn’t expose me as Merlin. I need to improve at nudging team compositions and votes more subtly, especially on critical missions, and better anticipate how my information will look from a non-Merlin perspective.

player_observations.Alice: Played Morgana in a way that blended well with village confusion, leveraging the Mission 2 fail to muddy suspicion between herself and other team members.
player_observations.Bob: Generally appeared cautious but trustworthy, and his inclusion on later missions without causing fails helped reinforce his good alignment image.
player_observations.Charlie: Looked solidly good and willing to be on early teams, but didn’t always push hard on leveraging mission results to narrow down evil candidates.
player_observations.Diana: As leader on the first failed mission, absorbed some suspicion but handled it calmly, neither over-defensive nor aggressively accusatory, which kept her in a gray area for many.
player_observations.Eve: Assassin play was subtle; participated in the early success and then the key fail, maintaining a low-to-medium profile that avoided making her the obvious kill target as non-Merlin.
player_observations.Frank: As Oberon, introduced some unpredictable noise; his participation in a failing mission without clear coordination made reads around him and his teams more confusing.
player_observations.Grace: Came across as analytical and proactive, and despite being good ended up on failing teams, which unintentionally helped evil by spreading doubt about her alignment.
player_observations.Henry: As Percival, tried to track Merlin-like behavior but was somewhat misled by the Morgana/Merlin ambiguity, showing hesitation in fully trusting his strongest read.
player_observations.Jack: Mordred play was low-key and effective; he avoided early exposure and only became more central on the final mission, where his presence helped secure the deciding fail.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed mostly under the radar as Mordred, letting the louder players and mission debates draw attention away from me, which helped evil reach three failed missions without my role being a central focus. I could improve by more actively steering team compositions earlier to better protect Merlin-cover and create clearer misreads for endgame, rather than mostly riding the momentum created by other evil players.

player_observations.Alice: Played Morgana convincingly by echoing reasonable logical takes, making it tougher to distinguish her from Merlin and adding noise around information-based reads.
player_observations.Bob: Tended to play straightforwardly and trust mission history heavily, which made him slower to adjust when the narrative turned against good.
player_observations.Charlie: Showed willingness to be on early teams and accept some risk, but didn’t press hard enough later to re-evaluate assumptions after multiple fails.
player_observations.Diana: Led with a collaborative tone and tried to build consensus, but this made her susceptible to being subtly steered by more assertive voices.
player_observations.Eve: As Assassin, stayed relatively calm and non-flashy, avoiding the classic "too tryhard" evil vibe and helping preserve ambiguity for the assassination.
player_observations.Frank: As Oberon, came off a bit disconnected from broader table logic, which actually helped create confusion and obscured the true evil configuration.
player_observations.Grace: Played analytically, focusing on team composition patterns, but sometimes over-weighted small samples from earlier missions, leading to some mis-clears.
player_observations.Henry: As Percival, clearly tried to track Merlin/Morgana signals but didn’t hard-push a single narrative, which made his reads feel cautious and sometimes hard to follow for others.
player_observations.Iris: As Merlin, did a good job not overcorrecting teams too aggressively, staying subtle enough that her knowledge wasn’t glaringly obvious and keeping the assassin guess non-trivial.
